div.p: The subscription resource is used to define a push-based transaction from a server to another system. A suscriber subscribes to one or more predefined Topics which the server supports. Subscribers typically receive only a subset of the total event notifications for a given topic by filtering on the content. The allowed filtering criteria are defined by the Topic resource, while requested filters are specified within the Subscription resource. Once a subscription is created, any resource change covered by a specified topic that meets the filtering criteria will cause a notification to be sent using the provided channel.
The server is able to send notifications without any information about the matching resource, with the ID of the matching resource, or with the entire resource.
Several different types of channels are supported:

ul.li: rest-hook: Notifications are sent via HTTP/S POST to a URL identified in the Subscription resource
websocket: Notifications are sent via WS/S to a client connected via a WebSocket
email/sms: Notifications are sent via SMTP or SMS to the nominated email address or phone number
message: Notifications are sent via FHIR messaging to the application identified in the URI

div.p: See below for further discussion of the various channels. Note that sending the entire resource creates security concerns that must be managed by the server.

Subscriptions are active resources; a server can only accept a subscription if it will execute the specified channel for any resources subsequently received. The subscription is no longer active once it is deleted from the server.

As an alternative to subscriptions, the RESTful API describes a polling-based subscription method using bundles and the history operation. This method of polling allows for a much tighter relationship between the client and the server that doesn't involve missing updates and/or deletes.

When using the Subscription resource, the FHIR server combines the roles of publisher and information distributer. Other arrangements of the publish and subscribe pattern describe separate agents for the two roles. Implementers may implement the Subscription resource using an architecture with separate agents, or using any other pub/sub architectire (e.g. see FHIRCast, or, more generally, W3C Pub/Sub).
